Claims.expr: find positive integers a, b, c such that (a^2, b^2) + (a, bc) + (b, ac) + (c, ab) = 199
(x, y) denotes the greatest common divisor of x and y
a, b, c are positive integers
let d1 = gcd(a, b), d2 = gcd(b, c), d3 = gcd(a, c)
\sum_{k=1}^n x_k^k = n \land \sum_{k=1}^n k x_k =  rac{n(n+1)}{2} \land  orall k=1\dots n, x_k \geq 0
orall k=2\dots n, f_k(t) = t^k - k t
orall k=2\dots n,  orall t > 0, f_k''(t) > 0
orall k=2\dots n, f_k 	ext{ is strictly convex on } (0, \infty)
orall k=2\dots n,  orall t \geq 0, f_k(t) \geq 1 - k \land (= \iff t=1)
\sum_{k=2}^n f_k(x_k) \geq \sum_{k=2}^n (1 - k) \land (= \iff  orall k=2\dots n, x_k = 1)
\sum_{k=1}^n x_k^k = n \land \sum_{k=1}^n k x_k =  rac{n(n+1)}{2} \land  orall k=(c - 476)\dots n, x_k \geq 0
all positive integers n such that A(n+2) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = 1
S subset of {1,...,n} is mediocre if for all a,b in S with (a+b)/2 integer then (a+b)/2 in S
A(n) = number of mediocre subsets of {1,...,n}
bijection between mediocre subsets of {1,...,n} and mediocre subsets of {1,...,n+1} not containing 1 by adding 1 to each element
A(n+1) = A(n) + B(n+1) where B(m) = number of mediocre subsets of {1,...,m} containing 1
mediocre S subset of {1,...,n+1} with 1 in S is mediocre as subset of {1,...,n+2}
number of mediocre S subset of {1,...,n+2} with 1 in S and n+2 not in S = B(n+1)
B(n+2) = B(n+1) + number of mediocre S subset of {1,...,n+2} with 1 in S and n+2 in S
A(n+2) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = number of mediocre S subset of {1,...,n+2} containing 1 and n+2
A(n+2) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = 1 iff the only mediocre S containing 1 and n+2 is {1,...,n+2}
n satisfies the equation iff the only mediocre subset of {1,...,n+2} containing 1 and n+2 is the full set
if n+1 is not a power of 2 then n+1 = 2^a * b with a >= 0 and b odd integer >1
average of 1 + m1 b and 1 + m2 b is 1 + ((m1 + m2)/2) b which is integer iff m1 + m2 even i.e. = 2 l with 0 <= l <= 2^a then in S
S is proper subset of {1,...,n+2} since |S| = 2^a + 1 < n + 2 = 2^a b + 1 as b > 1
if n+1 not power of 2 then there are at least two mediocre subsets containing 1 and n+2 (full set and S)
if n = 2^k - 1 for k >= 1 then the only mediocre subset of {1,...,n+2} containing 1 and n+2 is the full set
base case k=1 n=1 n+2=3: {1,3} not mediocre since average 2 not in it; {1,2,3} is mediocre
ind hyp: for k-1 the only mediocre subset of {1,...,2^{k-1} + 1} containing 1 and 2^{k-1} + 1 is full
for k, N = 2^k + 1, S contains (1 + N)/2 = 2^{k-1} + 1
let U = {1,...,2^{k-1} + 1}; S cap U contains 1 and 2^{k-1} + 1 and is mediocre in U
by ind hyp S cap U = U
let mid = 2^{k-1}; T = {x - mid | x in S cap {mid + 1, ..., N}}
all positive integers n such that A(n+(x_1 + 1)) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = 1

Math_Problem:
Solve the equation \[(a^{2},b^{2})+(a,bc)+(b,ac)+(c,ab)=199.\] in positive integers. (Here $(x,y)$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $x$ and $y$.) Instead of determining the positive integers satisfying the given equation on greatest common divisors, simply find $m = c - 476$, where $c$ is the positive integer appearing in the term $(c, ab)$. Let $n$ be a given positive integer. Solve the system \[x_1 + x_2^2 + x_3^3 + \cdots + x_n^n = n,\] \[x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 + \cdots + n x_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\] in real numbers such that $x_k \geq 0$ for all $k = m, m+1, \dots, n$. Instead of determining the complete nonnegative real solution to the system of equations, simply find $k = x_1 + 1$, where $x_1$ is the value of the first variable in that solution. Call a subset $S$ of $\{1, 2, \dots, n\}$ \emph{mediocre} if it has the following property:
Whenever $a$ and $b$ are elements of $S$ whose average is an integer, that average is also
an element of $S$. Let $A(n)$ be the number of mediocre subsets of $\{1,2,\dots,n\}$.
[For instance, every subset of $\{1,2,3\}$ except $\{1,3\}$ is mediocre, so $A(3) =7$.]
Find all positive integers $n$ such that $A(n+k) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = 1$.

Synthesised_By.A4395:
Solve the equation 
\[(a^{2},b^{2})+(a,bc)+(b,ac)+(c,ab)=199.\]
in positive integers. 
(Here $(x,y)$ denotes the greatest common divisor of $x$ and $y$.)

Synthesised_By.A4402:
Let $n$ be a given positive integer. Solve the system 
\[x_1 + x_2^2 + x_3^3 + \cdots + x_n^n = n,\]
\[x_1 + 2x_2 + 3x_3 + \cdots + nx_n = \frac{n(n+1)}{2}\]
in the set of nonnegative real numbers.

Synthesised_By.A3156:
Call a subset $S$ of $\{1, 2, \dots, n\}$ \emph{mediocre} if it has the following property:
Whenever $a$ and $b$ are elements of $S$ whose average is an integer, that average is also
an element of $S$. Let $A(n)$ be the number of mediocre subsets of $\{1,2,\dots,n\}$.
[For instance, every subset of $\{1,2,3\}$ except $\{1,3\}$ is mediocre, so $A(3) =7$.]
Find all positive integers $n$ such that $A(n+2) - 2A(n+1) + A(n) = 1$.
